items.title: Photos of Andrew reveal how ex-prince gave Jeffrey Epstein access to British high society
items.standfirst: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor reclines across five people in one photo watched by Ghislaine Maxwell at SandringhamPhotographs of the child sex offenders Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell released by the US justice department appear to show how Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor facilitated their access to British high society.Epstein and Maxwell are pictured hunting with the former prince at Balmoral and with him in the royal box at Ascot. A separate picture shows Maxwell outside 10 Downing Street. Continue reading...
items.content: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor reclines across five people in one photo watched by Ghislaine Maxwell at SandringhamPhotographs of the child sex offenders Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell released by the US justice department appear to show how Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor facilitated their access to British high society.Epstein and Maxwell are pictured hunting with the former prince at Balmoral and with him in the royal box at Ascot. A separate picture shows Maxwell outside 10 Downing Street. Continue reading...

items.title: US launches airstrikes against dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria
items.standfirst: Attacks come after two US soldiers and interpreter killed as Trump says US inflicting ‘very serious retaliation’The US military launched airstrikes against dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria on Friday in retaliation for an attack on US personnel, two US officials said on Friday.The attacks come after Donald Trump vowed to hit back after an attack last weekend in Syria by a suspected Islamic State member. Continue reading...
items.content: Attacks come after two US soldiers and interpreter killed as Trump says US inflicting ‘very serious retaliation’The US military launched airstrikes against dozens of Islamic State targets in Syria on Friday in retaliation for an attack on US personnel, two US officials said on Friday.The attacks come after Donald Trump vowed to hit back after an attack last weekend in Syria by a suspected Islamic State member. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump administration releases hundreds of thousands of Epstein files
items.standfirst: The US Justice Department began releasing several hundred thousand documents Friday from the investigation into convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, with more files to be published over the coming weeks. The publication marks the clearest opportunity yet to shed light on a politically explosive scandal, though experts caution that the government may cite legal constraints to obscure critical facts. Morgan Ayre has more.
items.content: The US Justice Department began releasing several hundred thousand documents Friday from the investigation into convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, with more files to be published over the coming weeks. The publication marks the clearest opportunity yet to shed light on a politically explosive scandal, though experts caution that the government may cite legal constraints to obscure critical facts. Morgan Ayre has more.

items.title: US justice department releases heavily redacted cache of Jeffrey Epstein files
items.standfirst: Photos included in tranche of documents as Democrats accuse Trump officials of failing to comply with lawPhotos from the first batch of the Jeffrey Epstein filesThe Department of Justice on Friday released a long-awaited and huge tranche of documents detailing its investigations into the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a major development in the lengthy saga that turned into one of the biggest political setbacks Donald Trump has suffered since his re-election last year.While significant portions of the files are redacted, those that were viewable included images of Epstein socializing with an array of prominent figures, including entertainers like Michael Jackson, Chris Tucker and Diana Ross, and the entrepreneur Richard Branson. Bill Clinton appears in several photos, including one in which he is in a swimming pool along with Epstein’s convicted accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell. The images also show former British royal Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor. Continue reading...
items.content: Photos included in tranche of documents as Democrats accuse Trump officials of failing to comply with lawPhotos from the first batch of the Jeffrey Epstein filesThe Department of Justice on Friday released a long-awaited and huge tranche of documents detailing its investigations into the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a major development in the lengthy saga that turned into one of the biggest political setbacks Donald Trump has suffered since his re-election last year.While significant portions of the files are redacted, those that were viewable included images of Epstein socializing with an array of prominent figures, including entertainers like Michael Jackson, Chris Tucker and Diana Ross, and the entrepreneur Richard Branson. Bill Clinton appears in several photos, including one in which he is in a swimming pool along with Epstein’s convicted accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell. The images also show former British royal Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The Justice Department released a new batch of files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein on Friday. Epstein survivor Sharlene Rochard joins with her reaction. Then, Spencer Kuvin, an attorney who represents some Epstein survivors, provides further analysis.

items.title: Survivors of Epstein’s abuse condemn justice department for only partly releasing files
items.standfirst: Lawyers for victims say they have been ‘repeatedly denied justice’ while deputy attorney general says more files will be releasedAnalysis: Trump over-promises and under-deliversRepresentatives for victims of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein condemned the US Department of Justice on Friday for only partially releasing investigative documents while at least one survivor said she felt “redeemed” by the documents.The documents were released under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, which mandated the disclosures by 19 December. The law allows for records to be withheld if they threaten current investigations, disrupt national security or identify Epstein’s victims. Continue reading...
items.content: Lawyers for victims say they have been ‘repeatedly denied justice’ while deputy attorney general says more files will be releasedAnalysis: Trump over-promises and under-deliversRepresentatives for victims of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein condemned the US Department of Justice on Friday for only partially releasing investigative documents while at least one survivor said she felt “redeemed” by the documents.The documents were released under the Epstein Files Transparency Act, which mandated the disclosures by 19 December. The law allows for records to be withheld if they threaten current investigations, disrupt national security or identify Epstein’s victims. Continue reading...

items.title: Inside the Epstein files: Famous faces, blacked-out pages
items.standfirst: Democrats on Friday voiced frustration that the long-awaited release of the Epstein files included many heavily redacted pages, claming it fell far short of what was mandated by the Epstein Files Transparency Act. The latest release includes photos of noted public figures in Epstein's social circle including former US president Bill Clinton, Mick Jagger and Michael Jackson.
items.content: Democrats on Friday voiced frustration that the long-awaited release of the Epstein files included many heavily redacted pages, claming it fell far short of what was mandated by the Epstein Files Transparency Act. The latest release includes photos of noted public figures in Epstein's social circle including former US president Bill Clinton, Mick Jagger and Michael Jackson.

items.title: U.S. strikes ISIS targets in Syria in retaliation for killing of 3 Americans

items.title: US launches retaliatory strikes on Islamic State group targets in Syria
items.standfirst: The US military has carried out a wave of air strikes against dozens of Islamic State group targets across central Syria, US officials said, in retaliation for a deadly attack on American personnel. The strikes follow President Donald Trump’s pledge to respond after two US soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed in an assault last weekend near Palmyra.
items.content: The US military has carried out a wave of air strikes against dozens of Islamic State group targets across central Syria, US officials said, in retaliation for a deadly attack on American personnel. The strikes follow President Donald Trump’s pledge to respond after two US soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed in an assault last weekend near Palmyra.

items.title: Musk Wins Reinstatement of His 2018 Pay Package as CEO
items.standfirst: Elon Musk won reinstatement of his 2018 pay package as chief executive of Tesla, after the Delaware Supreme Court reversed the finding of a judge who said the billionaire had improperly influenced board members who came up with the compensation plan. Jonathan Levin has more on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Elon Musk’s massive 2018 Tesla pay package restored by Delaware court
items.standfirst: Decision from state supreme court on deal once worth $56bn and now worth some $139bn overturns ruling that prompted angry Musk backlashElon Musk’s controversial $56bn pay package from Tesla was reinstated by the Delaware supreme court on Friday, two years after a lower court struck down the vast compensation deal as “unfathomable”.The reinstated pay package could be worth as much as $139bn today, according to the New York Times. The decision comes less than two months after Tesla shareholders approved a new plan that could be worth $1tn to Musk, already the world’s richest person, in a decade’s time. Musk’s fortune currently stands at an estimated $600bn. Continue reading...
items.content: Decision from state supreme court on deal once worth $56bn and now worth some $139bn overturns ruling that prompted angry Musk backlashElon Musk’s controversial $56bn pay package from Tesla was reinstated by the Delaware supreme court on Friday, two years after a lower court struck down the vast compensation deal as “unfathomable”.The reinstated pay package could be worth as much as $139bn today, according to the New York Times. The decision comes less than two months after Tesla shareholders approved a new plan that could be worth $1tn to Musk, already the world’s richest person, in a decade’s time. Musk’s fortune currently stands at an estimated $600bn. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump strikes deal with US drugmakers to cut Medicaid medicine costs
items.standfirst: Officials pledge ‘massive savings’ as companies agree to offer drugs at prices paid in other wealthy countriesDonald Trump and nine major pharmaceutical companies on Friday announced deals that will slash the prices of their medicines for the government’s Medicaid program and for cash payers, in his latest bid to align US costs with those in other wealthy nations.Bristol Myers Squibb, Gilead Sciences, and Merck and Roche’s US unit Genentech have struck deals. Novartis, Amgen, Boehringer Ingelheim, Sanofi and GSK have also signed on. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials pledge ‘massive savings’ as companies agree to offer drugs at prices paid in other wealthy countriesDonald Trump and nine major pharmaceutical companies on Friday announced deals that will slash the prices of their medicines for the government’s Medicaid program and for cash payers, in his latest bid to align US costs with those in other wealthy nations.Bristol Myers Squibb, Gilead Sciences, and Merck and Roche’s US unit Genentech have struck deals. items.title: Deadly knife rampage in Taiwan’s capital kills at least three people
items.standfirst: At least three people were killed and six more injured according to Taiwan’s national news agency, after a man threw smoke grenades into a train station before attacking bystanders at a mall with a large knife. NBC News’ Liz Kreutz reports.

items.title: Ukraine strikes Russian shadow fleet tanker in Mediterranean sea
items.standfirst: Ukraine on Friday said its drones had hit a vessel from Russia's shadow fleet – the first such strike in the neutral waters of the Mediterranean sea. Russia's shadow fleet transports sanctioned Russia oil by frequently changing flags and concealing ownership.
items.content: Ukraine on Friday said its drones had hit a vessel from Russia's shadow fleet – the first such strike in the neutral waters of the Mediterranean sea. Russia's shadow fleet transports sanctioned Russia oil by frequently changing flags and concealing ownership.

items.title: Ukraine 'hits Russian tanker in Mediterranean Sea for first time'

items.content: Ukraine has struck a Russian tanker in the Mediterranean Sea for the first time, a Kyiv intelligence source has said.

items.title: Ukraine attacks Russian ‘shadow’ tanker off Libyan coast
items.standfirst: Reportedly critical drone strike is first in Mediterranean since full-scale invasion began as maritime conflict grows‘There are hundreds’: tracking Russia’s ‘shadow fleet’ of oil tankersUkraine says it has attacked a Russian “shadow fleet” tanker with aerial drones 1,250 miles (2,000km) from its borders, in the first such strike in the Mediterranean Sea since Moscow’s full-scale invasion nearly four years ago.Friday’s strike off the coast of Libya, which reportedly caused critical damage, took place on the day of Vladimir Putin’s annual end of year press conference in which he said Russia would respond to recent Ukrainian attacks on shadow fleet tankers. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump refuses to rule out war with Venezuela as US sanctions Maduro family members
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump refused to rule out going to war with Venezuela in an NBC interview published on Friday, days after he ordered a naval blockade of sanctioned oil tankers coming to and leaving Venezuela. The Trump administration also imposed sanctions on family members and associates of Nicolas Maduro and his wife, ratcheting up the pressure on the Venezuelan president.
items.content: US President Donald Trump refused to rule out going to war with Venezuela in an NBC interview published on Friday, days after he ordered a naval blockade of sanctioned oil tankers coming to and leaving Venezuela. The Trump administration also imposed sanctions on family members and associates of Nicolas Maduro and his wife, ratcheting up the pressure on the Venezuelan president.

items.title: Trump and top aides refuse to rule out war with Venezuela
items.standfirst: President Nicolás Maduro orders Venezuelan navy to escort oil tankers after seizure by US forcesWhat action is Trump taking against Venezuela’s oil industry?Donald Trump and his top advisers have refused to rule out the potential for open conflict with Venezuela as Nicolás Maduro urged his navy to escort oil tankers defying the largest US fleet deployed in the region in decades.In an interview broadcast on Friday morning, Donald Trump told NBC News that going to war with Maduro’s regime remains on the table. “I don’t rule it out, no,” he said in a phone interview with the network. Continue reading...

items.title: Motive sought after suspect in Brown shooting, MIT professor's murder found dead

items.content: The Brown University shooting suspect was found dead in a storage unit in Salem, New Hampshire. Authorities believe he is also responsible for killing an MIT professor.

items.title: How a Reddit post led police to the suspected gunman in the Brown, MIT shootings
items.standfirst: The suspect in the Dec. 13 mass shooting on the campus of Brown University was found dead by suicide in a storage unit in Salem, New Hampshire, authorities said. He has been identified as 48-year-old Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, a former Brown grad student. Tom Hanson has more on how he was found.
items.content: The suspect in the Dec. 13 mass shooting on the campus of Brown University was found dead by suicide in a storage unit in Salem, New Hampshire, authorities said. He has been identified as 48-year-old Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, a former Brown grad student. Tom Hanson has more on how he was found.

items.title: Timeline of gunman in Brown University and MIT professor shootings
items.standfirst: Investigators are piecing together a detailed timeline of Claudio Neves Valente's actions before, during and after the Brown and MIT shootings.
items.content: Investigators are piecing together a detailed timeline of Claudio Neves Valente's actions before, during and after the Brown and MIT shootings.

items.title: A Reddit post helped find MIT and Brown shooting suspect. Here's what we know
items.standfirst: Details are beginning to emerge about the life of Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, the gunman who killed two and injured nine others in the attack at Brown University last week. He is also believed to have killed an MIT professor on Monday, police said.
items.content: Details are beginning to emerge about the life of Claudio Manuel Neves Valente, the gunman who killed two and injured nine others in the attack at Brown University last week. He is also believed to have killed an MIT professor on Monday, police said. (Image credit: Robert F. Bukaty)

clusters.title: Gaza famine over but situation 'remains critical', UN says
clusters.neutral_headline: Gaza no longer in famine but hunger levels remain critical, UN says

items.title: Gaza famine over but situation 'remains critical', UN says
items.standfirst: Improved aid access means there is no longer famine in Gaza, but the war-ravaged territory still faces emergency conditions, a UN-backed global hunger monitor said on Friday. Israel denied that there is a food shortage in Gaza, where around 1.6 million people are expected to face "crisis" levels of food insecurity in the coming months.
items.content: Improved aid access means there is no longer famine in Gaza, but the war-ravaged territory still faces emergency conditions, a UN-backed global hunger monitor said on Friday. Israel denied that there is a food shortage in Gaza, where around 1.6 million people are expected to face "crisis" levels of food insecurity in the coming months.

items.title: Gaza no longer in famine but hunger levels remain critical, UN says
items.standfirst: Monitor says almost one in eight people face food shortages as flooding and cold exacerbate humanitarian emergencyThe famine in Gaza has ended as a result of increased humanitarian aid deliveries into the territory, the UN said on Friday, though it warned that levels of hunger and the humanitarian situation remained critical.Almost one in eight people in Gaza still faced food shortages, the UN said, adding that persistent hunger had been made worse by winter flooding and the colder weather. Most people in Gaza live in tents or other substandard accommodation as Israel destroyed much of the housing and civilian infrastructure during its two-year war. Continue reading...
items.content: Monitor says almost one in eight people face food shortages as flooding and cold exacerbate humanitarian emergencyThe famine in Gaza has ended as a result of increased humanitarian aid deliveries into the territory, the UN said on Friday, though it warned that levels of hunger and the humanitarian situation remained critical.Almost one in eight people in Gaza still faced food shortages, the UN said, adding that persistent hunger had been made worse by winter flooding and the colder weather. Most people in Gaza live in tents or other substandard accommodation as Israel destroyed much of the housing and civilian infrastructure during its two-year war. Continue reading...

items.title: Africa's Startups, Fintech: The Race to Connect Millions | Bloomberg Next Africa
items.standfirst: In this episode of Next Africa, we dive into the continent's fast-evolving tech landscape, from booming fintech to startups tackling ...
items.content: In this episode of Next Africa, we dive into the continent's fast-evolving tech landscape, from booming fintech to startups tackling ...

items.title: Africa's Tech Disruptors | Bloomberg Next Africa
items.standfirst: In this episode of Next Africa, we dive into the continent’s fast-evolving tech landscape, from booming fintech to startups tackling Africa’s digital divide. Flutterwave CEO Olugbenga Agboola says the company is on track to achieve profitability. Optasia CEO Salvador Anglada shares how the firm aims to expand across the continent and abroad after its blockbuster IPO. Plus, we explore how Fibertime is working to close South Africa’s digital divide and Axian Group’s Hassanein Hiridjee discusses how stronger telecom infrastructure can underpin Africa’s AI-driven future. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: In this episode of Next Africa, we dive into the continent’s fast-evolving tech landscape, from booming fintech to startups tackling Africa’s digital divide. Flutterwave CEO Olugbenga Agboola says the company is on track to achieve profitability. Optasia CEO Salvador Anglada shares how the firm aims to expand across the continent and abroad after its blockbuster IPO. Plus, we explore how Fibertime is working to close South Africa’s digital divide and Axian Group’s Hassanein Hiridjee discusses how stronger telecom infrastructure can underpin Africa’s AI-driven future. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Charlie Kirk's widow Erika endorses JD Vance for president
clusters.neutral_headline: Charlie Kirk's widow Erika endorses JD Vance for president

items.title: Charlie Kirk's widow Erika endorses JD Vance for president
items.standfirst: Conservatives traded criticims at this year's annual Turning Point USA America Fest conference.
items.content: Conservatives traded criticims at this year's annual Turning Point USA America Fest conference.

items.title: Erika Kirk endorses JD Vance for president
items.standfirst: Vance was an ally of Turning Point USA before the killing of Charlie Kirk.
items.content: PHOENIX. Arizona — Turning Point USA CEO Erika Kirk has endorsed Vice President JD Vance for president, an early sign of influential support for a likely leading candidate in 2028. Kirk, who took over leadership of Turning Point after her husband, Charlie, was killed in September, announced her decision during a speech Thursday at the organization’s America Fest conference in Phoenix. Vance is scheduled to speak at the conference on Sunday. “We are going to get my husband’s friend JD Vance elected for 48 in the most resounding way possible,” Kirk said. Vance has not yet committed to running in 2028, but as vice president he is widely expected to seek the White House. TPUSA — founded by Charlie Kirk — holds major influence for the MAGA movement, particularly among young conservatives, and the early endorsement could give an early lead among the Republican hopefuls. “My attitude is the American people elected me to be vice president,” Vance told the New York Post in October. “I’m going to work as hard as I can to make the president successful over the next three years and three months, and if we get to a point where something else is in the offer, let’s handle it then.” Kirk made the endorsement in front of a crowd of thousands of people, many of whom are ardent supporters of President Donald Trump — and they responded with resounding applause. Vance and Charlie Kirk were particularly close before Kirk's death.
